channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Annual inflation rate picked up slightly in May, although less than expected, amid uncertainty about the economy
item.description: The inflation data released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics on Wednesday suggests President Donald Trump’s tariffs have yet to drive up the cost of everyday products.

item.title: Spreading protests. Guantánamo Bay. Rising prices. Israel sanctions. 23andMe data. Wildfire smoke. Exam cheating. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: The New Jersey gubernatorial race will pit Democratic congresswoman against Trump-backed Republican
item.description: Rep. Mikie Sherrill was projected to win the Democratic primary to replace term-limited Gov. Phil Murphy (D), according to the Associated Press. She will face businessman and former state Rep. Jack Ciattarelli, the AP reported. Ciattarelli came within three points of defeating Murphy four years ago. Sherrill flipped a GOP-held seat in 2018. Control of the governor's mansion has toggled between the parties.

item.title: U.S. and China agree to new framework to de-escalate trade war, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick says
item.description: The agreement, reached after trade negotiators met for two days in London, could also allow for a resolution around the shipment of rare earth minerals, according to Lutnick.

item.title: Trump administration planning major increase of Guantánamo deportations, including citizens of Britain, France and other allies
item.description: Plans have begun to send potentially thousands of foreigners to the detention site as early as this week — including citizens of Britain, France and Italy — with no plans of notifying their home governments, according to U.S. officials and documents provided to The Post. The preparations include medical screenings for 9,000 people to determine if they are healthy enough to be sent to the military base in Cuba.

item.title: Justice Department concludes that Trump can abolish national monuments and protected areas established by past presidents
item.description: A legal opinion released Tuesday by the Justice Department reverses a previous legal opinion issued in 1938 and could be laying the groundwork for President Donald Trump to abolish or dramatically shrink national monuments, which provide federal protections to millions of acres of government land.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Parent wants to push lonely tween to work on making new friends
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Parent wants to push lonely tween to work on making new friends

item.title: Trump’s military response to Los Angeles protests is expected to cost $134 million for 60 days, Pentagon official says
item.description: The U.S. military deployments that President Donald Trump has directed in response to unrest in Los Angeles are expected to cost $134 million for 60 days of operations, Pentagon official Bryn Woollacott MacDonnell told lawmakers at a hearing on Tuesday. The estimate includes food, transportation, housing and other associated costs.

item.title: D.C. court officials repeatedly lost track of teens wearing ankle monitors. The timing was deadly.
item.description: Teens accused of committing crimes in D.C. have gone missing after they let their GPS ankle monitor batteries die, a Washington Post investigation has found. Despite deadly consequences, D.C. judges have ordered widespread use of the devices for juveniles as young as 12.

item.title: A past president’s order in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: At least 9 killed in rare Austrian school shooting, police say
item.description: The perpetrator is also dead, police for the state of Styria said on social media, and several others were seriously injured. The school, BORG Dreierschützengasse in Graz, was evacuated.

item.title: L.A. protests. RFK Jr. Economic warning. Austria school shooting. Sly Stone. Dangerous heat. Glowing axolotls. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Smithsonian board says only its secretary has firing power, days after Trump claimed to have dismissed National Portrait Gallery director
item.description: The Board of Regents issued a statement backing the authority of Secretary Lonnie G. Bunch III, but added that he would instruct museums to “make any needed changes to ensure unbiased content.”

item.title: Trump mobilizes 2,000 additional National Guard troops to Los Angeles protests
item.description: The Pentagon, acting on orders from President Donald Trump, said 2,000 more members of the California National Guard would be mobilized to Los Angeles for “federal service," bringing the total to an estimated 4,000 National Guard troops and 700 Marines.

item.title: T.J. Oshie is retiring. A U.S. hockey hero at the 2014 Olympics, he became a fan favorite for the Capitals.
item.description: Oshie, 38, made the announcement Monday at the waterfront in Georgetown, seven years to the day after he and his teammates celebrated the franchise's only Stanley Cup title with a now-famous dive into the fountain. He did not play during the 2024-25 season while struggling with back issues, instead spending the last year of his contract on long-term injured reserve.

item.title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is ousting all members of a key CDC vaccination panel
item.description: In an op-ed published in the Wall Street Journal, Kennedy said the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, a group of experts who recommend vaccines, has been "plagued with persistent conflicts of interest." The move appears to contradict a pledge Kennedy made to Sen. Bill Cassidy (R-Louisiana) during the confirmation process to be health and human services secretary.

item.title: Pentagon sending hundreds of Marines to Los Angeles to backstop National Guard as Trump escalates feud with Gov. Gavin Newsom
item.description: The Marines will join National Guard troops whose deployment was ordered by President Donald Trump amid protests of his immigration policies.

item.title: Sly Stone has died at 82. The dazzling maestro of the Family Stone was known for the hits ‘Family Affair’ and ‘Everyday People.’
item.description: He electrified Woodstock crowds with his brand of psychedelic funk but fell into a fog of drug abuse at the height of his musical powers. His adventurism and ear for the times created an enduring soundtrack of the 1960s and early ’70s.

item.title: California sues Trump administration over deployment of National Guard troops to Los Angeles, says the move inflames situation
item.description: President Donald Trump ordered the deployment in response to protests against immigration raids without the consent of California Gov. Gavin Newsom (D). Newsom contends the move was illegal because it infringed on his role as commander in chief of the California National Guard.

item.title: Frederick Forsyth, thriller writer of ‘The Day of the Jackal,’ dies at 86
item.description: He wrote more than 20 novels, short stories and other works, selling more than 75 million copies in more than a dozen languages.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Craving ‘volatile’ affair partner over saving his marriage
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Craving ‘volatile’ affair partner over saving his marriage

item.title: D.C. failed to curb truancy — and fueled the biggest surge in youth crime in a generation
item.description: District leaders have long linked school attendance to youth crime, saying tackling one will curb the other. But a Washington Post investigation found that D.C. officials have failed to follow through on key initiatives that promised to keep students in class and out of trouble.

item.title: A Jersey legend in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: L.A. protests. Travel ban. Trump vs. Musk. Greta Thunberg. Mental health. Carlos Alcaraz. Tony Awards. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: ‘Maybe Happy Ending,’ ‘Purpose’ and ‘Sunset Blvd.’ among the big winners at the 2025 Tony Awards
item.description: Performers Cole Escola and Sarah Snook also took home prizes at the ceremony celebrating the best of Broadway.

item.title: Tornado watch in effect for D.C. region until 10 p.m.
item.description: Storms into this evening may become severe with the potential to produce damaging winds and hail in addition to heavy rain and lightning. A tornado or two is possible, especially in areas south and west of D.C.

item.title: Carlos Alcaraz beats Jannik Sinner in five-set stunner to repeat as French Open men's champion
item.description: Alcaraz rallied from two sets down and staved off three match points to defeat Sinner, the top-ranked player in the world, for his fifth Grand Slam singles championship. The 22-year-old Spaniard also won the 2022 U.S. Open and Wimbledon in 2023 and 2024.

item.title: Trump charts new territory as he bypasses California’s governor to deploy the National Guard
item.description: Legal experts questioned President Donald Trump’s response to unrest in Los Angeles, saying the military personnel involved will face strict limitations under the law.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Do you know who exports these foods to the U.S.? Test your knowledge.
item.description: The Post reviewed import data for eight common ingredients — including sugar, coffee, tea and oil — to see which countries send the United States the most of each item. We then compared the top country in each category against the current trade tariffs to see how imports could be affected. Some of the answers may surprise you as much as they did us.

item.title: Was my family the inspiration for a Dickens novel? I decided to investigate.
item.description: After my mother died, following my father by 15 years, I began to wonder: Might there have been some truth to what my father said? Was there a connection between my family’s history of legal feuding and Dickens?

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Trump administration activating National Guard in response to clashes over Los Angeles immigration raids, White House says
item.description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom (D) called the move to deploy 2,000 troops “purposefully inflammatory.” The mobilization comes after the acting head of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement accused L.A. Mayor Karen Bass (D) of taking “the side of chaos and lawlessness” as demonstrators clashed with law enforcement for a second straight day to protest immigration raids.

item.title: We asked 5 AI chatbots to summarize the words of doctors, lawyers and President Donald Trump. One bot was a clear winner.
item.description: We challenged the chatbots to decode legal contracts, simplify medical research, speed-read a novel and clarify Trump’s speeches. Some of the AI analysis was impressive, but some was downright dumb.

item.title: Inside the battles that shattered Trump and Musk’s alliance
item.description: Although the break between Elon Musk and President Donald Trump exploded into public view on Thursday, cracks in the alliance began to appear much earlier. As Musk’s “move fast and break things” bravado complicated the White House’s ambitions to remake American society, the billionaire alienated key members of the White House staff, including Chief of Staff Susie Wiles, and quarreled with Cabinet members, physically coming to blows with one.

item.title: NASA, Pentagon accelerate search for SpaceX alternatives amid Trump’s feud with Musk
item.description: Since Thursday’s acrimonious exchange between President Donald Trump and Elon Musk, at least three commercial space companies, Rocket Lab, Stoke Space and Blue Origin, have been contacted by government officials about the status of their rockets and when they might be available for government missions, according to four people familiar with the inquiries.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: After years of his lying about drinking, how do I trust my husband again?
item.description: Ask Sahaj: After years of his lying about drinking, how do I trust my husband again?

item.title: Coco Gauff tops Aryna Sabalenka to win the French Open. She is its first American women’s champion since Serena Williams in 2015.
item.description: In a rematch of their 2023 U.S. Open final, Gauff beat the top-ranked Sabalenka on Saturday to win her second Grand Slam singles championship. The 21-year-old American also won the 2023 U.S. Open.

item.title: In reversal, fencing around Dupont Circle Park is removed hours before WorldPride parade
item.description: The change comes shortly before the WorldPride parade was set to kick off in D.C. and follows days of intense criticism and confusion over the decision to close the park at the center of the District’s historic LGBTQ community.

item.title: DOGE dismissed White House staffers’ security warnings before installing Musk’s Starlink internet service in the complex
item.description: The U.S. DOGE Service and its allies in the Trump administration ignored White House communications experts worried about potential security breaches when DOGE personnel set up Starlink satellite internet service this year, three people familiar with the matter told The Washington Post.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Colleges can directly pay athletes after judge grants final approval of landmark settlement
item.description: Judge Claudia Wilken ruled Friday to approve the revised terms of the $2.8 billion settlement in the House v. NCAA antitrust case, establishing that college athletics programs can pay their varsity athletes via revenue sharing starting in the 2025-26 academic year and beyond.

item.title: Colleagues question whether Del. Eleanor Holmes Norton is still the best warrior to fight for D.C.
item.description: Several elected officials and allies of the longtime delegate in the House are publicly raising questions about whether the deeply respected civil rights icon is the effective and vigorous leader the city needs.

item.title: Pentagon inquiry into Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth's Signal usage explores whether he, or an aide, shared military attack plans
item.description: The Defense Department inspector general’s office also has questioned potential witnesses about whether Hegseth's aides were ordered to delete sensitive messages from the unclassified chat application, according to people familiar with the inquiry and communications reviewed by The Washington Post.

item.title: Divided Supreme Court lets DOGE access Social Security data of millions of Americans
item.description: The conservative justices sided with Trump administration on two emergency requests related to the U.S. DOGE Service, clearing the way for its employees to access sensitive data and internal systems at the Social Security Administration while litigation continues and shielding DOGE from having to immediately disclose records to a government watchdog group.

item.title: Maryland man who was wrongly deported to El Salvador now in U.S. custody and charged with human smuggling
item.description: The criminal charges against Kilmar Abrego García in Tennessee come weeks after the Supreme Court ordered Trump officials to facilitate his return from the Salvadoran prison where he was erroneously sent. The ruling ignited a standoff with the president, his lawyers and Cabinet members.

item.title: Proud Boys leaders sue Justice Department over Jan. 6 prosecutions
item.description: Henry “Enrique” Tarrio and four others convicted after the Jan. 6 Capitol breach say the government violated their constitutional rights. They’re seeking $100 million.

item.title: D.C. police lieutenant sentenced to 18 months for leaking to Proud Boys
item.description: Shane Lamond said he was merely gathering intelligence from Henry “Enrique” Tarrio, but a judge convicted him of obstructing justice and making false statements to investigators.

item.title: Amid fallout from Trump's attacks on law firms, former Manhattan U.S. attorney leaves firm that made deal with the president
item.description:
Damian Williams, the former top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, is leaving the law firm Paul Weiss to join Jenner & Block, defecting from a firm that struck a deal with the Trump administration to sign on with one that fought it in court.
Williams is the highest-profile attorney to join the exodus from firms that made deals with President Donald Trump this year.

item.title: Carolyn Hax chat: Friend wrongly cut me off. Her daughter wants us to reconnect.
item.description: Carolyn Hax chat: Friend wrongly cut me off. Her daughter wants us to reconnect.
